**Super Bowl XXXVIII** was an [American football](/wiki/American_football
"American football") game between the [National Football
Conference](/wiki/National_Football_Conference "National Football Conference")
(NFC) champion [Carolina Panthers](/wiki/2003_Carolina_Panthers_season "2003
Carolina Panthers season") and the [American Football
Conference](/wiki/American_Football_Conference "American Football Conference")
(AFC) champion [New England Patriots](/wiki/2003_New_England_Patriots_season
"2003 New England Patriots season") to decide the [National Football
League](/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League") (NFL)
champion for the [2003 season](/wiki/2003_NFL_season "2003 NFL season"). The
Patriots defeated the Panthers by the score of 32-29. The game was played at
[Reliant Stadium](/wiki/NRG_Stadium "NRG Stadium") in [Houston,
Texas](/wiki/Houston "Houston"), on Sunday, February 1, 2004. At the time,
this was the most watched Super Bowl ever with 144.4 million viewers.[5]

The Panthers were making their first ever Super Bowl appearance after posting
an 11–5 regular season record. They also made it the second straight year that
a team from the [NFC South](/wiki/NFC_South "NFC South") division made the
[Super Bowl](/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl"), with the [Tampa Bay
Buccaneers](/wiki/Tampa_Bay_Buccaneers "Tampa Bay Buccaneers") winning [Super
Bowl XXXVII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXVII "Super Bowl XXXVII"). The Patriots were
seeking their second Super Bowl title in three years after posting a 14–2
record.

NFL fans and sports writers widely consider this game one of the most well-
played and thrilling Super Bowls; _[Sports
Illustrated](/wiki/Sports_Illustrated "Sports Illustrated")_ writer [Peter
King](/wiki/Peter_King_\(sportswriter\) "Peter King \(sportswriter\)") hailed
it as the "Greatest Super Bowl of all time."[6] Although neither team could
score in the first and third quarters, they ended up with a combined total of
868 yards and 61 points. The game was scoreless for a Super Bowl record 26:55
before the two teams combined for 24 points prior to halftime. The clubs then
combined for a Super Bowl record 37 points in the fourth quarter. The contest
was finally decided when the Patriots kicker [Adam
Vinatieri](/wiki/Adam_Vinatieri "Adam Vinatieri")'s 41-yard field goal was
made with four seconds left. Patriots quarterback [Tom Brady](/wiki/Tom_Brady
"Tom Brady") was named [Super Bowl MVP](/wiki/Super_Bowl_MVP "Super Bowl MVP")
for the second time in his career.

The game is also known for [its controversial halftime
show](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXVIII_halftime-show_controversy "Super Bowl XXXVIII
halftime-show controversy") in which [Janet Jackson](/wiki/Janet_Jackson
"Janet Jackson")'s breast, adorned with a [nipple
shield](/wiki/Nipple_shield_\(jewelry\) "Nipple shield \(jewelry\)"), was
exposed by [Justin Timberlake](/wiki/Justin_Timberlake "Justin Timberlake")
for about half a second, in what was later referred to as a "[wardrobe
malfunction](/wiki/Wardrobe_malfunction "Wardrobe malfunction")".[7] Along
with the rest of the halftime show, it led to an immediate crackdown by the
[Federal Communications Commission](/wiki/Federal_Communications_Commission
"Federal Communications Commission") (FCC), and widespread debate on perceived
indecency in broadcasting.[7]

##
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XXXVIII&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background")]

NFL owners voted to award Super Bowl XXXVIII to Houston during their November
1, 2000 meeting held in Atlanta. This was the first Super Bowl to be played in
a stadium with a retractable roof (but it was eventually closed during the
game). It also marked the first time in 4 tries that the Patriots played a
Super Bowl that was not in New Orleans. This game marked a six-month stretch
for Texas hosting the Super Bowl, [NCAA men's Division I basketball Final
Four](/wiki/NCAA_Men%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Championship "NCAA Men's
Division I Basketball Championship") and [Major League
Baseball](/wiki/Major_League_Baseball "Major League Baseball") (MLB) [All-Star
Game](/wiki/Major_League_Baseball_All-Star_Game "Major League Baseball All-
Star Game"). The [Final
Four](/wiki/2004_NCAA_Men%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Tournament#Final_four_2
"2004 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament") was played at the
[Alamodome](/wiki/Alamodome "Alamodome") in San Antonio and the [MLB All-Star
Game](/wiki/2004_Major_League_Baseball_All-Star_Game "2004 Major League
Baseball All-Star Game") was also played in Houston at nearby [Minute Maid
Park](/wiki/Minute_Maid_Park "Minute Maid Park").

Beginning with this game, all Super Bowl games have been played on the first
Sunday in February every year. This is based on the 22 weeks necessary from
opening week through Super Bowl Sunday, which includes scheduling no games
until after Labor Day, granting a bye week to each team during the sixteen-
game season, and granting a bye week to the teams qualifying for the Super
Bowl after each wins their respective conference championship game.
Consequently, the Super Bowl is currently scheduled no earlier than February 1
and no later than February 7.

This game set the record for most [Roman numerals](/wiki/Roman_numerals "Roman
numerals") in a Super Bowl title (seven). This will not be matched until Super
Bowl LXXVIII after the 2043 NFL season and Super Bowl LXXXVII after the 2052
season, and not surpassed until Super Bowl LXXXVIII after the 2053 season.

### The Panthers go from 1–15 to the Super
Bowl[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XXXVIII&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: The Panthers go from 1–15 to the Super Bowl")]

Main article: [2003 Carolina Panthers
season](/wiki/2003_Carolina_Panthers_season "2003 Carolina Panthers season")

The Panthers made their first trip to the Super Bowl after posting a [one-win
regular season just two years earlier](/wiki/2001_Carolina_Panthers_season
"2001 Carolina Panthers season"). The franchise was only in their ninth year
of existence, joining the league as an [expansion team](/wiki/Expansion_team
"Expansion team") in [1995](/wiki/1995_NFL_season "1995 NFL season"). In just
their second season, they posted a 12–4 regular season record and advanced to
the NFC Championship Game, but lost to the eventual Super Bowl champion [Green
Bay Packers](/wiki/Green_Bay_Packers "Green Bay Packers") 30–13 (the Packers
coincidentally went on to defeat the Patriots in [Super Bowl
XXXI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXI "Super Bowl XXXI") 35–21). But from
[1997](/wiki/1997_NFL_season "1997 NFL season") onward, they had just one non-
losing season (an 8–8 finish in [1999](/wiki/1999_NFL_season "1999 NFL
season")) until they finally suffered through a franchise worst 1–15 record in
[2001](/wiki/2001_NFL_season "2001 NFL season"), winning only the first game
of the regular season against the Minnesota Vikings. After that year, head
coach [George Seifert](/wiki/George_Seifert "George Seifert") was relieved of
his duties and replaced by [John Fox](/wiki/John_Fox_\(NFL\) "John Fox
\(NFL\)"), former defensive coordinator for the [New York
Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York Giants") who helped lead the Giants to
[Super Bowl XXXV](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXV "Super Bowl XXXV") in
[2000](/wiki/2000_NFL_season "2000 NFL season").

With John Fox at the helm and the team taking advantage of the [free
agent](/wiki/Free_agent "Free agent") market and the [salary
cap](/wiki/Salary_cap "Salary cap") rules, the Panthers improved in
[2002](/wiki/2002_NFL_season "2002 NFL season"), finishing with a 7–9 record.
Then in 2003, they recorded an 11–5 record and won the [NFC
South](/wiki/NFC_South "NFC South").

One of the free agents that Carolina signed before the 2003 season was
quarterback [Jake Delhomme](/wiki/Jake_Delhomme "Jake Delhomme"). Delhomme was
not picked by any team in the [NFL Draft](/wiki/NFL_Draft "NFL Draft"), but
later joined the [New Orleans Saints](/wiki/New_Orleans_Saints "New Orleans
Saints") as an undrafted free agent in [1998](/wiki/1998_NFL_season "1998 NFL
season"). Delhomme also then played for the [NFL Europe](/wiki/NFL_Europe "NFL
Europe")'s [Frankfurt Galaxy](/wiki/Frankfurt_Galaxy "Frankfurt Galaxy") in
1999, and along with Pat Barnes, he was part of the "double-headed quarterback
monster" that led the Galaxy to a [World Bowl](/wiki/World_Bowl "World Bowl")
victory over the [Barcelona Dragons](/wiki/Barcelona_Dragons "Barcelona
Dragons").

Although he only played 6 games in his 5 seasons with New Orleans, the
Panthers signed Delhomme in 2003 to be the backup to starting quarterback
[Rodney Peete](/wiki/Rodney_Peete "Rodney Peete"). However, after the Panthers
fell to a 17–0 third quarter deficit in their first game of the season against
the [Jacksonville Jaguars](/wiki/Jacksonville_Jaguars "Jacksonville Jaguars"),
gaining only one first down and 36 offensive yards, Fox immediately replaced
Peete with Delhomme. Delhomme ended up leading Carolina to a 24–23 comeback
victory over the Jaguars.

Delhomme became the team's starting quarterback for the rest of the season,
throwing for 3,219 yards and 19 touchdowns, with 16 interceptions. The team's
main receiving threat was multi-talented third-year wide receiver [Steve
Smith](/wiki/Steve_Smith_Sr. "Steve Smith Sr."), who also specialized as a
kickoff and punt returner. Smith caught 88 passes for 1,110 yards and 7
touchdowns, rushed for 42 yards, gained 439 yards and another touchdown
returning punts, and recorded 309 kickoff return yards. Wide receiver [Muhsin
Muhammad](/wiki/Muhsin_Muhammad "Muhsin Muhammad") was also a constant
breakaway threat, recording 54 receptions for 837 yards and 3 touchdowns.

However, the Panthers' strength on offense was their running game, led by
running backs [Stephen Davis](/wiki/Stephen_Davis_\(American_football\)
"Stephen Davis \(American football\)") and [DeShaun
Foster](/wiki/DeShaun_Foster "DeShaun Foster"). Davis was the team's leading
rusher with a franchise record 1,444 yards and 8 touchdowns, while Foster
rushed for 429 yards and caught 26 passes for 207 yards. Carolina also had
running back [Rod Smart](/wiki/Rod_Smart "Rod Smart") on their roster, who
became widely known for his [XFL](/wiki/XFL "XFL") debut jersey name "He Hate
Me" during that league's only season in 2001. During 2003, Smart was primarily
used as the Panthers' other kickoff returner, recording 947 yards and one
touchdown.

On defense, Carolina's main strength was their defensive line, anchored by
defensive ends [Julius Peppers](/wiki/Julius_Peppers "Julius Peppers") (7
sacks and 3 forced fumbles) and [Mike Rucker](/wiki/Mike_Rucker "Mike Rucker")
(12 sacks and 1 interception), and [Pro Bowl](/wiki/Pro_Bowl "Pro Bowl")
defensive tackle [Kris Jenkins](/wiki/Kris_Jenkins "Kris Jenkins") (5 sacks
and 1 fumble recovery). The secondary was led by defensive backs [Reggie
Howard](/wiki/Reggie_Howard "Reggie Howard") (2 interceptions), [Mike
Minter](/wiki/Mike_Minter "Mike Minter") (3 interceptions for 100 return yards
and 2 touchdowns), [Deon Grant](/wiki/Deon_Grant "Deon Grant") (3
interceptions), and [Ricky Manning Jr.](/wiki/Ricky_Manning_Jr. "Ricky Manning
Jr.") (3 interceptions for 33 return yards and 1 touchdown).

### The Patriots go for two out of
three[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XXXVIII&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: The Patriots go for two out of three")]

Main article: [2003 New England Patriots
season](/wiki/2003_New_England_Patriots_season "2003 New England Patriots
season")

Despite their victory in [Super Bowl XXXVI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXVI "Super Bowl
XXXVI") after the [2001 season](/wiki/2001_NFL_season "2001 NFL season"), the
Patriots stumbled early in the [2002 season](/wiki/2002_NFL_season "2002 NFL
season"), recorded a 9–7 regular season record, and failed to make the
playoffs.

Then, New England seemed to implode before the 2003 season ever started. Five
days before their opening game against the [Buffalo
Bills](/wiki/2003_Buffalo_Bills_season "2003 Buffalo Bills season"), Pro Bowl
safety [Lawyer Milloy](/wiki/Lawyer_Milloy "Lawyer Milloy"), one of the
Patriots' defensive leaders, was unexpectedly cut by the team after refusing
to restructure his contract. The move devastated many of the New England
players, while Milloy immediately signed with the Bills two days later. With
the Patriots seemingly in emotional disarray, Buffalo defeated New England,
31–0, with Milloy forcing an interception and recording one sack and five
tackles.

However, after a 2–2 start, the Patriots ended up winning their last 12 games
(including a mirror 31–0 shutout of the Bills in the final week) to earn a
league-best 14–2 record.

[Tom Brady](/wiki/Tom_Brady "Tom Brady"), the Super Bowl XXXVI
[MVP](/wiki/Super_Bowl_Most_Valuable_Player_Award "Super Bowl Most Valuable
Player Award"), had become the team's permanent starter in 2002 after
quarterback [Drew Bledsoe](/wiki/Drew_Bledsoe "Drew Bledsoe") left the team to
lead the Bills. Brady had a solid season in 2003, completing 317 out of 527
(60.2 percent) of his passes for 3,620 yards and 23 touchdowns, with only 12
interceptions. His primary weapon was second year wide receiver [Deion
Branch](/wiki/Deion_Branch "Deion Branch"), who caught 57 passes for 803
yards. Another key contributor was wide receiver [David
Givens](/wiki/David_Givens "David Givens"), who filled in for the injured
starter [David Patten](/wiki/David_Patten "David Patten"). Givens recorded 34
receptions for 510 yards and 6 touchdowns. Other weapons in the passing game
included veteran wide receiver [Troy Brown](/wiki/Troy_Brown "Troy Brown"),
who had 40 receptions, 472 yards, 4 touchdowns, and 293 yards returning punts,
and tight end [Daniel Graham](/wiki/Daniel_Graham "Daniel Graham") who
recorded 28 catches, 409 yards, and 4 touchdowns.

In the backfield, the team's rushing game was led by running backs [Antowain
Smith](/wiki/Antowain_Smith "Antowain Smith") and [Kevin
Faulk](/wiki/Kevin_Faulk "Kevin Faulk"), who carried the ball equally. Smith
was the team's leading rusher with 642 yards and 3 touchdowns, while Faulk
rushed for 638 yards and caught 48 passes for 440 yards.

New England's defense was retooled before the 2003 season when the team signed
veteran safety [Rodney Harrison](/wiki/Rodney_Harrison "Rodney Harrison") as a
free agent and traded for defensive lineman [Ted
Washington](/wiki/Ted_Washington "Ted Washington"). With these additions, the
Patriots led the league in fewest passing yards allowed per attempt (5.64),
fewest passing touchdowns allowed (11), and most interceptions (29). They also
ranked 4th in fewest rushing yards allowed (1,434) and 7th in fewest total
yards (4,919).

Washington helped anchor New England's defensive line, recording 32 tackles
and 2 sacks. Pro Bowl defensive tackle [Richard Seymour](/wiki/Richard_Seymour
"Richard Seymour") also contributed with 8 sacks. Behind them, the Patriots
had 3 outstanding linebackers: Pro Bowl linebacker [Willie
McGinest](/wiki/Willie_McGinest "Willie McGinest") (5.5 sacks, 2 fumble
recoveries and 1 interception), [Mike Vrabel](/wiki/Mike_Vrabel "Mike Vrabel")
(9.5 sacks, 1 fumble recovery, four forced fumbles, and 2 interceptions), and
[Tedy Bruschi](/wiki/Tedy_Bruschi "Tedy Bruschi") (131 tackles, 2 sacks, 1
fumble recovery, 3 interceptions, and 2 touchdowns).

Harrison became the veteran leader in the secondary, recording 92 tackles, 3
interceptions, and 3 sacks. Meanwhile, Pro Bowl cornerback [Ty
Law](/wiki/Ty_Law "Ty Law") recorded 6 interceptions, cornerback (and ex-
Panthers player) [Tyrone Poole](/wiki/Tyrone_Poole "Tyrone Poole") had 6
interceptions for 112 return yards and 1 touchdown, and rookie safety [Eugene
Wilson](/wiki/Eugene_Wilson_\(football\) "Eugene Wilson \(football\)")
recorded 4 interceptions. Overall, the secondary combined for 19
interceptions.

### Common opponents of both
teams[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XXXVIII&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Common opponents of both teams")]

The Patriots and Panthers both played against the [AFC South](/wiki/AFC_South
"AFC South") and [NFC East](/wiki/NFC_East "NFC East") in the regular season.
The Patriots lost to the [Washington
Redskins](/wiki/2003_Washington_Redskins_season "2003 Washington Redskins
season") 20–17 in Week Four but swept the rest of the NFC East and the entire
AFC South; the Patriots shut out [Dallas](/wiki/2003_Dallas_Cowboys_season
"2003 Dallas Cowboys season") in bitter cold and edged [the
Giants](/wiki/2003_New_York_Giants_season "2003 New York Giants season") in
the rain while hammering [Philly](/wiki/2003_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "2003
Philadelphia Eagles season") following the infamously erroneous "They hate
their coach" quote from [Tom Jackson](/wiki/Tom_Jackson_\(American_football\)
"Tom Jackson \(American football\)"); the Patriots also edged [the
Titans](/wiki/2003_Tennessee_Titans_season "2003 Tennessee Titans season"),
[Houston](/wiki/2003_Houston_Texans_season "2003 Houston Texans season") in
overtime, and [former division rival
Indianapolis](/wiki/2003_Indianapolis_Colts_season "2003 Indianapolis Colts
season") in shootouts while routing
[Jacksonville](/wiki/2003_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "2003 Jacksonville
Jaguars season") (which, like Carolina, had entered the NFL in
[1995](/wiki/1995_Jacksonville_Jaguars_season "1995 Jacksonville Jaguars
season")) in the regular season, and then edged the Titans and hammered the
Colts in the playoffs. The Panthers had less success, going 6–4 against the
two divisions, losing to the Titans and Houston while defeating Jacksonville
and the Colts, and defeating Washington and the Giants while losing to
Philadelphia and Dallas in the regular season, then routing the Cowboys and
edging the Eagles in the playoffs.

###
Playoffs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XXXVIII&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Playoffs")]

See also: [2003–04 NFL playoffs](/wiki/2003%E2%80%9304_NFL_playoffs "2003–04
NFL playoffs")

Since the Panthers finished with the third best regular season record in the
NFC, they had to win three playoff games to reach the Super Bowl. The [St.
Louis Rams](/wiki/2003_St._Louis_Rams_season "2003 St. Louis Rams season") and
the [Philadelphia Eagles](/wiki/2003_Philadelphia_Eagles_season "2003
Philadelphia Eagles season") had better regular season records at 12–4, and
thus under the playoff format, each would have to win two playoff games to
reach the league championship game. Against Carolina's first opponent, the
[Dallas Cowboys](/wiki/2003_Dallas_Cowboys_season "2003 Dallas Cowboys
season"), Delhomme threw for 273 yards and a touchdown, Davis recorded 104
rushing yards and a touchdown, and kicker [John Kasay](/wiki/John_Kasay "John
Kasay") made 5 field goals, en route to a thorough 29–10 victory.

The Panthers then eliminated the Rams on the road, 29–23 in double overtime.
St. Louis built a 6–0 lead early in the second quarter, but Carolina took the
lead after Muhammad's fumble recovery in the end zone. Both teams spent the
rest of the second and the third quarter exchanging field goals before Brad
Hoover's 7-yard rushing touchdown gave the Panthers a 23–12 fourth quarter
lead. However, the Rams rallied back with a touchdown, a successful [two-point
conversion](/wiki/Two-point_conversion "Two-point conversion"), and a field
goal to send the game into overtime. Both teams missed field goals in the
first overtime period, but Delhomme threw a 69-yard touchdown pass to Smith on
the first play of the second overtime period to win the game.

The Panthers then went on the road again to eliminate the Eagles in the [NFC
Championship Game](/wiki/NFC_Championship_Game "NFC Championship Game"), 14–3.
Philadelphia was coming off of a 20–17 overtime win over the [Green Bay
Packers](/wiki/2003_Green_Bay_Packers_season "2003 Green Bay Packers season"),
that included quarterback [Donovan McNabb](/wiki/Donovan_McNabb "Donovan
McNabb")'s 28-yard pass to [Freddie Mitchell](/wiki/Freddie_Mitchell "Freddie
Mitchell") on a famous play known as "[4th and 26](/wiki/4th_and_26 "4th and
26")". This was the third consecutive NFC Championship Game appearance for
Philadelphia, and thus they were heavily favored to win. But Carolina's
defense only allowed a field goal and held McNabb to just 10 of 22 completions
for 100 yards. Ricky Manning also intercepted McNabb 3 times. Although
Carolina's offense only scored 14 points, it was more than enough for the team
to earn their first trip to the Super Bowl with a 14–3 win.

The Panthers became the first No. 3 seed to advance to the Super Bowl since
the league expanded to a 12-team playoff format in 1990. In doing so, they
were also the first division winner to advance to the league championship
after playing _three_ playoff games. All other instances up to this point
where teams advanced to the Super Bowl after playing all three rounds of the
playoffs were [wild card](/wiki/Wild_card_\(sports\)#National_Football_League
"Wild card \(sports\)") teams in Super Bowls [XV](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XV "Super
Bowl XV"), [XX](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XX "Super Bowl XX"),
[XXVII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXVII "Super Bowl XXVII"),
[XXXII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXII "Super Bowl XXXII"),
[XXXIV](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXIV "Super Bowl XXXIV"), and
[XXXV](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXV "Super Bowl XXXV"). Prior to [Super Bowl
XVII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XVII "Super Bowl XVII"), the [Miami
Dolphins](/wiki/Miami_Dolphins "Miami Dolphins") and [Washington
Redskins](/wiki/Washington_Redskins "Washington Redskins") both won three
playoff games to reach the Super Bowl, but that came during the [strike-
shortened](/wiki/1982_NFL_strike "1982 NFL strike")
[1982](/wiki/1982_NFL_season "1982 NFL season") season when the regular season
was reduced to nine games and the playoffs were expanded to 16 teams, with no
teams receiving first-round byes. Since then, there have been six instances of
teams advancing to the Super Bowl after playing three playoff games: the
[Pittsburgh Steelers](/wiki/2005_Pittsburgh_Steelers_season "2005 Pittsburgh
Steelers season") in [Super Bowl XL](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XL "Super Bowl XL") as
the No. 6 seeded team, the [Indianapolis
Colts](/wiki/2006_Indianapolis_Colts_season "2006 Indianapolis Colts season")
in [Super Bowl XLI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLI "Super Bowl XLI") as the No. 3 seed,
the [New York Giants](/wiki/2007_New_York_Giants_season "2007 New York Giants
season") in [Super Bowl XLII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLII "Super Bowl XLII") as the
No. 5 seed, the [Arizona Cardinals](/wiki/2008_Arizona_Cardinals_season "2008
Arizona Cardinals season") in [Super Bowl XLIII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLIII "Super
Bowl XLIII") as the No. 4 seed, the [Green Bay
Packers](/wiki/2010_Green_Bay_Packers_season "2010 Green Bay Packers season")
in [Super Bowl XLV](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLV "Super Bowl XLV") as the No. 6 seed,
and again the [New York Giants](/wiki/2011_New_York_Giants_season "2011 New
York Giants season") in [Super Bowl XLVI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLVI "Super Bowl
XLVI") as the No. 4 seed. The Colts, Cardinals, and the Giants in 2011, like
the Panthers, were division winners in those years (Although in the Colts
case, they played the No. 4 seeded [New England
Patriots](/wiki/2006_New_England_Patriots_season "2006 New England Patriots
season") in the AFC Championship that year, ensuring at least the second
division winner to play three rounds to make it to the Super Bowl.), and all
but the Cardinals went on to win it all. The Super Bowl would mark the third
game (out of four) of the playoffs in which Carolina scored 29 points.

Meanwhile, the Patriots first defeated the [Tennessee
Titans](/wiki/2003_Tennessee_Titans_season "2003 Tennessee Titans season"),
17–14, in one of the coldest games in NFL history, with temperatures reaching
4 °F (−15 °C). New England jumped to 14–7 lead in the first half with a
touchdown pass by Brady and a touchdown run from Smith. However, quarterback
[Steve McNair](/wiki/Steve_McNair "Steve McNair")'s 11-yard touchdown pass to
receiver [Derrick Mason](/wiki/Derrick_Mason "Derrick Mason") tied the game in
the third period. With 4:06 remaining in the game, Patriots kicker [Adam
Vinatieri](/wiki/Adam_Vinatieri "Adam Vinatieri") made a 46-yard field goal to
take the lead. New England's defense later clinched a victory as they stopped
the Titans from scoring on fourth down on their last drive of the game.

New England then eliminated the [Indianapolis
Colts](/wiki/2003_Indianapolis_Colts_season "2003 Indianapolis Colts season"),
24–14, in the [AFC Championship Game](/wiki/AFC_Championship_Game "AFC
Championship Game"). The Colts entered the game leading the NFL in passing
yards and ranked third in total offensive yards. With quarterback [Peyton
Manning](/wiki/Peyton_Manning "Peyton Manning"), wide receiver [Marvin
Harrison](/wiki/Marvin_Harrison "Marvin Harrison"), and running back [Edgerrin
James](/wiki/Edgerrin_James "Edgerrin James"), the Colts had scored 79 points
in their 2 playoff victories against the [Denver Broncos](/wiki/Denver_Broncos
"Denver Broncos") and the [Kansas City Chiefs](/wiki/Kansas_City_Chiefs
"Kansas City Chiefs"), including a 38–31 victory over the Chiefs in the first
[punt](/wiki/Punt_\(gridiron_football\) "Punt \(gridiron football\)")-less
game in NFL playoff history. However, New England's defense dominated the
Colts, only allowing 14 points, intercepting 4 passes from Manning (3 of them
by [Ty Law](/wiki/Ty_Law "Ty Law")), and forcing a safety. Although New
England's offense only scored one touchdown, Vinatieri scored 5 field goals to
make up the difference.

## Broadcasting and
entertainment[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XXXVIII&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Broadcasting and entertainment")]

The game was broadcast on television in the [United
States](/wiki/United_States "United States") by [CBS](/wiki/NFL_on_CBS "NFL on
CBS"), with [Greg Gumbel](/wiki/Greg_Gumbel "Greg Gumbel") handling the [play-
by-play](/wiki/Sports_commentary "Sports commentary") duties and [color
commentator](/wiki/Color_commentator "Color commentator") [Phil
Simms](/wiki/Phil_Simms "Phil Simms") in the broadcast booth. [Armen
Keteyian](/wiki/Armen_Keteyian "Armen Keteyian") and [Bonnie
Bernstein](/wiki/Bonnie_Bernstein "Bonnie Bernstein") roamed the sidelines.
[Jim Nantz](/wiki/Jim_Nantz "Jim Nantz") hosted all the events with help from
his fellow cast members from _[The NFL Today](/wiki/The_NFL_Today "The NFL
Today")_ : [Dan Marino](/wiki/Dan_Marino "Dan Marino"), [Deion
Sanders](/wiki/Deion_Sanders "Deion Sanders"), and [Boomer
Esiason](/wiki/Boomer_Esiason "Boomer Esiason"). This would be the final Super
Bowl game Greg Gumbel would call; as before the [2004
season](/wiki/2004_NFL_season "2004 NFL season") began, he and Nantz would
switch roles; though by the time CBS next aired a [Super
Bowl](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLI "Super Bowl XLI"); [James
Brown](/wiki/James_Brown_\(sportscaster\) "James Brown \(sportscaster\)") was
brought in as host of _[The NFL Today](/wiki/The_NFL_Today "The NFL Today")_
while Gumbel had moved to a secondary play-by-play role.

[Westwood One](/wiki/NFL_on_Westwood_One "NFL on Westwood One") carried the
game nationwide over terrestrial radio with [Marv Albert](/wiki/Marv_Albert
"Marv Albert") on play-by-play and Boomer Esiason on color commentary, with
[Jim Gray](/wiki/Jim_Gray_\(sportscaster\) "Jim Gray \(sportscaster\)")
hosting the pregame and halftime shows. Locally, [Gil Santos](/wiki/Gil_Santos
"Gil Santos") and [Gino Cappelletti](/wiki/Gino_Cappelletti "Gino
Cappelletti") called the game for the Patriots and [Bill
Rosinski](/wiki/Bill_Rosinski "Bill Rosinski") and [Eugene
Robinson](/wiki/Eugene_Robinson "Eugene Robinson") served that position for
the Panthers.

After the postgame coverage was complete, CBS aired the season premiere for
_[Survivor: All Stars](/wiki/Survivor:_All_Stars "Survivor: All Stars")_.

### Pregame
ceremonies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XXXVIII&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Pregame ceremonies")]

Both teams passed on the opportunity for their starters to be introduced
individually before the game, a move perpetuated by the Patriots in [Super
Bowl XXXVI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXVI "Super Bowl XXXVI").

The game was held exactly one year, to the day, after the [Space Shuttle
Columbia disaster](/wiki/Space_Shuttle_Columbia_disaster "Space Shuttle
Columbia disaster"), in Houston, the same city as the [Johnson Space
Center](/wiki/Johnson_Space_Center "Johnson Space Center"). Thus, the lost
crew of the _Columbia_ was honored in a pregame tribute by singer [Josh
Groban](/wiki/Josh_Groban "Josh Groban"), performing "[You Raise Me
Up](/wiki/You_Raise_Me_Up "You Raise Me Up")". Also appearing on the field was
the crew of [STS-114](/wiki/STS-114 "STS-114"), the "Return to Flight" [Space
Shuttle](/wiki/Space_Shuttle "Space Shuttle") mission that eventually launched
_[Space Shuttle Discovery](/wiki/Space_Shuttle_Discovery "Space Shuttle
Discovery")_ on July 26, 2005.[8][9] Houston-native
[Beyoncé](/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9 "Beyoncé") then sang the [national
anthem](/wiki/National_anthem "National anthem"). [Aerosmith](/wiki/Aerosmith
"Aerosmith") performed [Baby, Please Don't Go](/wiki/Baby,_Please_Don%27t_Go
"Baby, Please Don't Go") and [Dream On](/wiki/Dream_On_\(Aerosmith_song\)
"Dream On \(Aerosmith song\)") as part of the pre-show ceremony.[10]

The [coin toss](/wiki/Coin_flipping "Coin flipping") ceremony featured former
NFL players and Texas natives [Earl Campbell](/wiki/Earl_Campbell "Earl
Campbell"), [Ollie Matson](/wiki/Ollie_Matson "Ollie Matson"), [Don
Maynard](/wiki/Don_Maynard "Don Maynard"), [Y. A. Tittle](/wiki/Y._A._Tittle
"Y. A. Tittle"), [Mike Singletary](/wiki/Mike_Singletary "Mike Singletary"),
[Gene Upshaw](/wiki/Gene_Upshaw "Gene Upshaw"). Tittle tossed the coin.

The NFL logo was painted at midfield for the first time since [Super Bowl
XXX](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXX "Super Bowl XXX"), and the Super Bowl XXXVIII logo
was placed on the 25-yard lines. From Super Bowls [XXXI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXI
"Super Bowl XXXI") through [XXXVII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXVII "Super Bowl
XXXVII"), the Super Bowl logo was painted at midfield, and the helmets of the
teams painted at the 30-yard lines. From [Super Bowl VI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_VI
"Super Bowl VI") through [Super Bowl XXX](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXX "Super Bowl
XXX"), the NFL logo was painted on the 50-yard line, except for Super Bowls
[XXV](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXV "Super Bowl XXV") and [XXIX](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXIX
"Super Bowl XXIX"). The Super Bowl XXV logo was painted at midfield and the
NFL logo was painted at each 35-yard line. In [Super Bowl
XXIX](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXIX "Super Bowl XXIX"), the NFL 75th Anniversary logo
was painted at midfield with the Super Bowl logo at each 30-yard line.

### Halftime
show[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XXXVIII&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Halftime show")]

Further information: [Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime-show
controversy](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXVIII_halftime-show_controversy "Super Bowl
XXXVIII halftime-show controversy")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Justin_Timberlake_Cannes_2013.jpg/238px-
Justin_Timberlake_Cannes_2013.jpg)](/wiki/File:Justin_Timberlake_Cannes_2013.jpg)

Janet Jackson and Justin Timberlake (pictured) became the center of
controversy during the end of the halftime show

The most controversial and widely discussed moment of Super Bowl XXXVIII came
during halftime. The show was produced by [Viacom](/wiki/Viacom "Viacom")'s
[MTV](/wiki/MTV "MTV") and [CBS Sports](/wiki/CBS_Sports "CBS Sports"), and
was sponsored by [America Online](/wiki/America_Online "America Online")'s
TopSpeed software for dial-up Internet service. The show was themed supposedly
around MTV's [Choose or Lose](/wiki/MTV#Choose_or_Lose "MTV") vote
campaign,[11] however beyond some flag imagery, [Jessica
Simpson](/wiki/Jessica_Simpson "Jessica Simpson")'s declaration that Houston
should "Choose to Party!" and a vague call to action for younger persons to
vote in a celebrity montage the first minute of the program and an audio outro
about choices, the theme was not called out for the remainder of the show.[12]

After a brief appearance by Simpson, the show began with a joint performance
by marching bands the [Spirit of Houston](/wiki/Spirit_of_Houston "Spirit of
Houston"), from the [University of Houston](/wiki/University_of_Houston
"University of Houston"), and the "[Ocean of Soul](/wiki/Ocean_of_Soul "Ocean
of Soul")" of [Texas Southern University](/wiki/Texas_Southern_University
"Texas Southern University"). Next, [Janet Jackson](/wiki/Janet_Jackson "Janet
Jackson") made her first appearance, singing "[All for
You](/wiki/All_for_You_\(Janet_Jackson_song\) "All for You \(Janet Jackson
song\)")". Then, [P. Diddy](/wiki/Sean_Combs "Sean Combs"),
[Nelly](/wiki/Nelly "Nelly"), and [Kid Rock](/wiki/Kid_Rock "Kid Rock")
appeared respectively, and performed a mixture of their hits.

After Jackson's performance of her song "[Rhythm Nation](/wiki/Rhythm_Nation
"Rhythm Nation")", [Justin Timberlake](/wiki/Justin_Timberlake "Justin
Timberlake") appeared, and he and Jackson sang a duet of Timberlake's song
"[Rock Your Body](/wiki/Rock_Your_Body "Rock Your Body")". The performance
featured many suggestive dance moves by both Timberlake and Jackson. As the
song reached the final line, "I'm gonna have you naked by the end of this
song," Timberlake pulled off a part of Jackson's costume, revealing her outer
right [breast](/wiki/Breast "Breast") (adorned with a large, sun-shaped
[nipple shield](/wiki/Nipple_shield_\(jewelry\) "Nipple shield \(jewelry\)"),
a piece of [jewelery](/wiki/Jewelery "Jewelery") worn to accentuate the
appearance of a [nipple piercing](/wiki/Nipple_piercing "Nipple piercing")).
CBS quickly cut to an aerial view of the stadium, however the action was too
late to be effective. Many people considered this [indecent
exposure](/wiki/Indecent_exposure "Indecent exposure"), and numerous viewers
contacted the network to complain, saying it was inappropriate in the context
of a [football](/wiki/American_football "American football") game. This was
the most rewatched moment in [TiVo](/wiki/TiVo "TiVo") history.[13]

Just before the start of the second half, a British [streaker](/wiki/Streaking
"Streaking"), [Mark Roberts](/wiki/Mark_Roberts_\(streaker\) "Mark Roberts
\(streaker\)"), ran onto the field disguised as a referee, undressed, and
performed a dance wearing only a [thong](/wiki/Thong_\(clothing\) "Thong
\(clothing\)"). He was tackled to the ground by Patriots linebacker [Matt
Chatham](/wiki/Matt_Chatham "Matt Chatham") and arrested. It is customary for
American television to avoid broadcasting such events, but it was later shown
on _[Late Show with David Letterman](/wiki/Late_Show_with_David_Letterman
"Late Show with David Letterman")_. He received a $1,000 fine for
trespassing.[14]

## Game
summary[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XXXVIII&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Game summary")]

This game is noted for its unusual scoring pattern between the teams. Nearly
ninety percent of the first half and all of the third quarter were scoreless.
Twenty-four points were scored in the last three minutes of the first half,
and a record 37 points were scored in the fourth quarter.

### First
Quarter[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XXXVIII&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: First Quarter")]

Most of the first half was a defensive struggle, with neither team able to
score until late in the second quarter, despite several early scoring
opportunities for New England. After Carolina was forced to punt on their
opening drive, Patriots receiver [Troy Brown](/wiki/Troy_Brown "Troy Brown")
gave his team great field position with a 28-yard return to the Panthers
47-yard line. The Patriots subsequently marched to the 9-yard line, but
Carolina kept them out of the end zone and [Adam
Vinatieri](/wiki/Adam_Vinatieri "Adam Vinatieri") missed a 31-yard field goal
attempt. The Patriots forced Carolina to punt after 3 plays and again got the
ball with great field position, receiving [Todd
Sauerbrun](/wiki/Todd_Sauerbrun "Todd Sauerbrun")'s 40-yard punt at the
Panthers 49-yard line. New England then drove to the 31-yard line, but on
third down, linebacker [Will Witherspoon](/wiki/Will_Witherspoon "Will
Witherspoon") tackled Brown for a 10-yard loss on an end-around play, pushing
the Patriots out of field goal range.

### Second
Quarter[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XXXVIII&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Second Quarter")]

Later on, New England drove 57 yards to the Panthers 18-yard line with 6
minutes left in the second quarter, but once again they failed to score as
Carolina kept them out of the end zone and Vinatieri's 36-yard field goal
attempt was blocked by Panthers defender [Shane Burton](/wiki/Shane_Burton
"Shane Burton").

Meanwhile, the Carolina offense was stymied by the New England defense, with
quarterback [Jake Delhomme](/wiki/Jake_Delhomme "Jake Delhomme") completing
just one out of his first nine passes, sacked three times, and fumbling once.
That fumble occurred 3 plays after Vinatieri's second missed field goal;
Delhomme lost the ball while being sacked by linebacker [Mike
Vrabel](/wiki/Mike_Vrabel "Mike Vrabel"), and Patriots defensive tackle
[Richard Seymour](/wiki/Richard_Seymour "Richard Seymour") recovered the ball
at the Panthers 20-yard line; by this point of the game the Panthers had
suffered a net loss of nine yards on twenty offensive snaps.

Two plays later, New England faced a third down and 7, but quarterback [Tom
Brady](/wiki/Tom_Brady "Tom Brady") scrambled 12 yards to the 5-yard line for
a first down. Then wide receiver [Deion Branch](/wiki/Deion_Branch "Deion
Branch") caught a 5-yard touchdown pass from Brady on the next play. The play
was a play-action fake to [Antowain Smith](/wiki/Antowain_Smith "Antowain
Smith"). Carolina's [Dan Morgan](/wiki/Dan_Morgan "Dan Morgan") bit on the
route, causing the touchdown.

Branch's touchdown came after 26:55 had elapsed in the game, setting the
record for the longest amount of time a Super Bowl remained scoreless. The
play also suddenly set off a scoring explosion from both teams for the
remainder of the first half.

The Panthers stormed down the field on their ensuing possession, driving 95
yards in 8 plays, and tying the game on a 39-yard touchdown pass from Delhomme
to wide receiver [Steve Smith](/wiki/Steve_Smith_Sr. "Steve Smith Sr.") with
just 1:07 left in the half.

The Patriots immediately countered with a 6-play, 78-yard scoring drive of
their own. Starting from their own 22-yard line, Brady completed a 12-yard
pass to wide receiver [David Givens](/wiki/David_Givens "David Givens"). Then
after throwing an incompletion, Brady completed a long pass to Branch, who
caught it at the Panthers 24-yard line in stride before being tackled at the
14-yard line for a 52-yard gain. Three plays later, Givens caught a 5-yard
touchdown from Brady to give New England a 14–7 lead with only 18 seconds left
in the half. The Patriots decided to [squib kick](/wiki/Squib_kick "Squib
kick") the ensuing kickoff to prevent a long return, but their plan backfired
as Carolina tight end [Kris Mangum](/wiki/Kris_Mangum "Kris Mangum") picked up
the ball at his own 35-yard line and returned it 12 yards to the 47. The
Patriots expected a pass play from the Panthers, but instead running back
[Stephen Davis](/wiki/Stephen_Davis_\(American_football\) "Stephen Davis
\(American football\)") ran for 21 yards on the next play to set up kicker
[John Kasay](/wiki/John_Kasay "John Kasay")'s 50-yard field goal as time
expired in the half, cutting Carolina's deficit to 14–10.

### Third
Quarter[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XXXVIII&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Third Quarter")]

The third quarter was scoreless as each team exchanged punts twice. However,
with 3:57 left in the period, the Patriots put together a 71-yard, 8-play
scoring drive, featuring tight end [Daniel Graham](/wiki/Daniel_Graham "Daniel
Graham")'s 33-yard reception to advance to the Carolina 9-yard line.

### Fourth
Quarter[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XXXVIII&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Fourth Quarter")]

Running back [Antowain Smith](/wiki/Antowain_Smith "Antowain Smith") then
capped off the drive with a 2-yard touchdown run on the second play on the
fourth quarter to increase their lead, 21–10. This was the start of another
scoring explosion, one that became one of the biggest explosions in Super Bowl
history, with both teams scoring a combined 37 points in the last 15 minutes,
the most ever in a single quarter of a Super Bowl.

Delhomme started out Carolina's ensuing drive with a 13-yard completion to
wide receiver [Muhsin Muhammad](/wiki/Muhsin_Muhammad "Muhsin Muhammad").
After committing a false start penalty on the next play, Delhomme completed a
pair of passes to Smith for gains of 18 and 22 yards. Running back [DeShaun
Foster](/wiki/DeShaun_Foster "DeShaun Foster") then scored on a 33-yard
touchdown run, cutting the Panthers' deficit to 21–16 after Delhomme's 2-point
conversion pass fell incomplete. The Patriots responded on their ensuing
possession by driving all the way to Carolina's 9-yard line, but the drive
ended when Panthers defensive back [Reggie Howard](/wiki/Reggie_Howard "Reggie
Howard") intercepted a third down pass from Brady in the end zone. Then on 3rd
down from his own 15-yard line, Delhomme threw for the longest play from
scrimmage in Super Bowl history, an 85-yard touchdown completion to Muhammad.
Carolina's 2-point conversion attempt failed again, but they took their first
lead of the game, 22–21, with 6:53 remaining. It was the first time in Super
Bowl history a team down 10+ points during the 4th quarter had come back to
take the lead. Three other times teams have come back to tie the game; the
[Tennessee Titans](/wiki/Tennessee_Titans "Tennessee Titans") against the Rams
in [Super Bowl XXXIV](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXIV "Super Bowl XXXIV"), the Rams
against the Patriots in [Super Bowl XXXVI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXVI "Super Bowl
XXXVI"), and the Patriots against the Falcons in [Super Bowl
LI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_LI "Super Bowl LI").

However, New England retook the lead on their next drive, advancing 68 yards
with the aid of a pair of completions from Brady to Givens for gains of 18 and
25 yards. Once again the Patriots were faced with third down and goal, but
this time they scored with Brady's 1-yard pass to Vrabel, who had lined up in
an eligible tight end position. Then on a two-point conversion attempt,
running back [Kevin Faulk](/wiki/Kevin_Faulk "Kevin Faulk") took a direct snap
and ran into the end zone to make the score 29–22. Despite amassing over 1,000
combined yards, Faulk's two-point conversion constituted the only points he
scored all season.

The Panthers countered on their next possession. Foster started the drive with
a 9-yard run and a 7-yard reception. After that, Delhomme completed a 19-yard
pass to Muhammad, followed by a 31-yard completion to receiver [Ricky
Proehl](/wiki/Ricky_Proehl "Ricky Proehl"). Then Proehl, who caught the fourth
quarter game-tying touchdown pass against the Patriots in [Super Bowl
XXXVI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXVI "Super Bowl XXXVI") two years earlier for the
[St. Louis Rams](/wiki/2001_St._Louis_Rams_season "2001 St. Louis Rams
season"), finished the drive with a 12-yard touchdown reception. Kasay's
ensuing extra point tied the game, 29–29, with 1:08 to play in regulation and
it appeared that the game would be the first Super Bowl ever to go into
overtime.

However, Kasay kicked the ensuing kickoff out of bounds, giving New England
the ball on their own 40-yard line. Brady led the Patriots offense down the
field with a 13-yard pass to Brown on second down. An offensive pass
interference penalty on Brown pushed New England back to their own 43-yard
line, but another 13-yard reception to Brown and a 4-yard pass to Graham
brought up a critical 3rd down and 3 from the Carolina 40-yard line. The
Panthers defense could not prevent the Patriots from gaining the first down,
as Brady completed a 17-yard pass to Branch. On the next play, Vinatieri
kicked a 41-yard field goal to give New England the lead, 32–29, with four
seconds left in the game. Carolina failed on their last chance, as [Rod
Smart](/wiki/Rod_Smart "Rod Smart") went nowhere on the ensuing kickoff, and
the Patriots had won their second Super Bowl in three years. This was the
fourth Super Bowl to be decided on a field goal in the final seconds ([Super
Bowl V](/wiki/Super_Bowl_V "Super Bowl V") was won on a last second kick by
the Baltimore Colts' [Jim O'Brien](/wiki/Jim_O%27Brien_\(American_football\)
"Jim O'Brien \(American football\)") to defeat the [Dallas
Cowboys](/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys"), [Super Bowl
XXV](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXV "Super Bowl XXV") had the Buffalo Bills' [Scott
Norwood](/wiki/Scott_Norwood "Scott Norwood") miss [his field goal
chance](/wiki/Wide_Right_\(Buffalo_Bills\) "Wide Right \(Buffalo Bills\)")
against the [New York Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York Giants"), and in
[Super Bowl XXXVI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXVI "Super Bowl XXXVI") Vinatieri made
his to defeat the [St. Louis Rams](/wiki/St._Louis_Rams "St. Louis Rams")).

### Statistical
overview[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XXXVIII&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Statistical overview")]

The game set a number of marks for offensive production. The two teams
combined for 868 yards of total offense, the second-highest total in Super
Bowl history. Both starting quarterbacks threw for at least 300 yards for only
the second time in Super Bowl history, with [Dan Marino](/wiki/Dan_Marino "Dan
Marino") and [Joe Montana](/wiki/Joe_Montana "Joe Montana") each passing for
at least 300 yards in [Super Bowl XIX](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XIX "Super Bowl XIX").
This was also only the second Super Bowl to feature one 100-yard receiving
performance on each team, with Deion Branch and Muhsin Muhammad each reaching
100 yards. [Andre Reed](/wiki/Andre_Reed "Andre Reed") and [Michael
Irvin](/wiki/Michael_Irvin "Michael Irvin") first accomplished the feat in
[Super Bowl XXVII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXVII "Super Bowl XXVII").

The 37 total points scored in the 4th quarter were the most combined points in
a 4th quarter in a Super Bowl and the most in any quarter by two teams.
Washington's 35 points in [Super Bowl XXII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXII "Super Bowl
XXII") was the previous high for most combined points in a single quarter in a
Super Bowl. The fourth quarter was the second in Super Bowl history to have
five touchdowns scored in a single quarter, the first being when the Redskins
had five in Super Bowl XXII in the second quarter. It was also the first time
in Super Bowl history that both teams would score at least two touchdowns in
the same quarter.

Delhomme finished the game with 16 completions out of 33 attempts for 323
yards, three touchdowns, and no interceptions for a passer rating of 113.6. He
was seen standing on the field during the Patriots' post-game celebration; he
later commented: "I wanted to catch up to the moment of what it feels like to
be on the other side, to be on this side, the losing side. To let it sink in,
to hurt, so when we start practice in the fall, the two-a-days and there are
days during the season when I’m tired and I want to go home, but I need to
watch that extra film. I want to get back there, but I want to get on the
other side of that field. They rope you off, the losing team basically. I just
want to get on the other side of that rope. I just wanted to watch and let it
sink in and hurt a little bit. When I have a tough day, I’ll just think about
that feeling and it will make me dig down just a little deeper."[15]

Muhsin Muhammad caught four passes for 140 yards, an average of 35 yards per
catch, and a touchdown. Steve Smith caught four passes for 80 yards and a
touchdown. He also returned a punt for two yards, and returned a kickoff for
30 yards, giving him 112 total yards. Proehl caught four passes for 71 yards
and a touchdown. Proehl joined [Jerry Rice](/wiki/Jerry_Rice "Jerry Rice") as
only two players to score touchdowns with two different teams in Super Bowls.

Tom Brady's 32 completions were the most in Super Bowl history. His 48
attempts were the most for a winning quarterback. His 354 yards passing is now
the fifth best total in Super Bowl history. Brady's passer rating for this
game was 100.5. Branch was the top receiver of the game with 10 receptions for
143 yards and a touchdown. Brown caught 8 passes for 76 yards, and returned
four punts for 40 yards. Antowain Smith was the top rusher of the game with 83
yards and a touchdown.

  * Most sportsbooks had the Patriots as seven-point favorites entering the game. As the Patriots only won by three points, the Patriots failed to cover this [spread](/wiki/Spread_betting "Spread betting").
  * The [over-under](/wiki/Over-under "Over-under") bet was set at 37.5 by most sportsbooks. As the total combined score of the two teams was 61 points, the over bet won.[17]

Tom Sifferman became the second official to work consecutive Super Bowls on
the field. The first was [Jim
Tunney](/wiki/Jim_Tunney_\(American_football_official\) "Jim Tunney \(American
football official\)"), the referee for Super Bowls [XI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XI
"Super Bowl XI") and [XII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XII "Super Bowl XII").
